title.en: Nature Treasure Hunt & Found Object Display
title.es: Nature Treasure Hunt & Found Object Display

description.en: Nature Treasure Hunt & Found Object Display
description.es: Nature Treasure Hunt & Found Object Display

20.label: 20 Minutes
20.bestFor: Tight schedules, younger students (K-1), daily scheduling Total time: 10 min story + 10 min activity = 20 minutes
20.activityName: Nature Treasure Hunt & Found Object Display

steps.title: Outdoor Exploration (5 min)
steps.description: Take students outside. Challenge: Find 3-5 interesting natural treasures (rocks, sticks, leaves). Remind them to only take what's already on the ground

steps.title: Quick Sharing (2 min)
steps.description: Gather in circle. Each student shows one favorite find: I found a smooth rock! or Look at this curly stick!

steps.title: Simple Sorting (2 min)
steps.description: Sort treasures into piles—all rocks together, all sticks together, all leaves together

steps.title: Label & Take Home (1 min)
steps.description: On scrap paper, write or draw My Nature Treasures. Place items in bag to take home

discussionQuestions: Where did you find your treasure?
Did you have to pay money to get these treasures?
What makes your treasure special or beautiful?

30.label: 30 Minutes
30.bestFor: Standard class periods, grades 1-3, weekly scheduling Total time: 10 min story + 20 min activity = 30 minutes
30.activityName: Nature Treasure Hunt & Found Object Display
materials: Egg cartons OR small boxes for display
Index cards or paper scraps for labels

steps.title: Pre-Hunt Discussion (3 min)
steps.description: Review story. Ask: What treasures did Layla and friends find? Explain: We're looking for rocks, sticks, leaves, and other natural treasures. Only collect what's on the ground—leave living plants alone.

steps.title: Nature Treasure Hunt (10 min)
steps.description: Students explore outdoor space with bags/baskets. Encourage finding variety: different shapes, colors, sizes. Guide observations: What textures do you notice? What colors?

steps.title: Sorting & Counting (4 min)
steps.description: Return indoors. Dump out collections. Sort by type. Count: I have ___ rocks, ___ sticks, ___ leaves

steps.title: Create Simple Display (5 min)
steps.description: Use egg carton or box to arrange treasures. Place rocks in one section, leaves in another. Create simple label: My Nature Collection by [Name]

steps.title: Gallery Walk (3 min)
steps.description: Set displays on tables. Students walk around viewing each other's collections. Share compliments

discussionQuestions: How are your rocks different from your neighbor's rocks?
Did anyone find two leaves that look the same? How are they different?
What's the most interesting thing you found? Why?
In the story, Mr. Mason said nature gives gifts for free. What does that mean?
What's something you might buy at a store? What's something you can find for free?

45.label: 45 Minutes
45.bestFor: Block schedules, grades 3-4, deeper exploration Total time: 10 min story + 35 min activity = 45 minutes
45.activityName: Nature Treasure Hunt & Found Object Display
materials: Display boxes or shadow boxes (one per student/small group)
Optional: nature field guide or identification cards

steps.title: Preparation & Scientific Mindset (5 min)
steps.description: Discuss observation techniques. Review story connection: Scientists observe nature just like Layla did. Introduce vocabulary: texture, pattern, classify, observe. Show field guide if available. Set collection goals: Find 8-10 diverse items

steps.title: Extended Nature Exploration (12 min)
steps.description: Students explore with baskets and magnifying glasses. Encourage close observation: Look at the veins in the leaf. Feel the texture of the rock. Take mental notes of where items were found

steps.title: Scientific Sorting & Classification (8 min)
steps.description:
- Sort by multiple criteria: type, size, color, texture
   - Use magnifying glasses to observe details
   - Try to identify items using field guide (oak leaf vs. maple leaf, smooth river rock vs. rough)
   - Complete observation sheet: Name of item, where found, color, size, texture, what's special about it

steps.title: Detailed Drawing (5 min)
steps.description: Choose favorite treasure. Observe with magnifying glass. Draw scientifically with labels pointing to interesting features. Write: I found this [item] near [location]. It's special because [reason]

steps.title: Museum-Quality Display (8 min)
steps.description:
- Arrange treasures in display box artistically
   - Consider balance, color arrangement, size progression
   - Create professional labels for each item or category
   - Add title card: [Name]'s Nature Discovery Collection
   - Optional: Include written descriptions of most interesting finds

steps.title: Presentation & Reflection (2 min)
steps.description: Students present one treasure to partner or small group, explaining where found and why it's valuable even though it's free

discussionQuestions: Why do you think some rocks are smooth and some are rough?
How do leaves from different trees compare?
What makes something valuable if it doesn't cost money?
How does finding free treasures in nature compare to buying toys or objects?
If you collected treasures like this every week, what kind of collection could you build?
What did you learn about nature's gifts from this activity?
How can we make sure nature keeps giving these gifts to everyone?
extensionIdeas: Research specific items (tree types, rock formation, decomposition)
Create nature journals documenting observations from multiple outings
Organize class nature museum with rotating exhibits
Press leaves and create scientific specimen collection
Write creative stories featuring found treasures as characters

20.label: 20 Minutes
20.bestFor: Tight schedules, younger students (K-1), daily scheduling Total time: 10 min story + 10 min activity = 20 minutes
materials: Potting soil or dirt from outside
Fast-growing seeds (radish, bean, or sunflower - 2-3 per student)
Popsicle sticks or paper for plant markers

steps.title: Seed Introduction (2 min)
steps.description: Show different seeds. Ask: How can something this tiny become a whole plant? Connect to story: Frances showed the friends her seed jars.

steps.title: Plant Seeds (5 min)
steps.description: Each student fills cup 2/3 with soil, pokes 1-2 finger holes, drops in seeds, covers gently

steps.title: Label & Water (2 min)
steps.description: Write name on cup or popsicle stick marker. Gently water

steps.title: Place in Growing Area (1 min)
steps.description: Put cups in sunny windowsill or designated spot

steps.title: Quick Discussion (2 min)
steps.description: How long until we see a plant? What does the plant need? How is this like saving money?

discussionQuestions: What does a seed need to grow?
Can we eat the plant tomorrow? Why not?
In the story, why did Riley have to be patient?

30.label: 30 Minutes
30.bestFor: Standard class periods, grades 1-3, weekly scheduling Total time: 10 min story + 20 min activity = 30 minutes
materials: Seeds (3 varieties: fast-growing like radish/bean, medium like sunflower, slower like tomato)
Seed observation journals (simple printable or notebook paper folded)

steps.title: Seed Exploration (5 min)
steps.description:
- Display 3 seed types. Pass around for students to observe
   - Compare sizes, shapes, colors
   - Discuss: Which do you think grows fastest? Why?
   - Connect to story: Frances had jars and jars of different seeds.

steps.title: Create Observation Journal (4 min)
steps.description:
- Fold paper to create simple booklet or use printable
   - First page: Draw the seed before planting
   - Write: My seed is a ___. Today's date: ___
   - Prediction: I think it will grow in ___ days

steps.title: Planting Process (7 min)
steps.description:
- Each student chooses one seed type (or gets all three for comparison)
   - Fill clear cup 2/3 with soil
   - Plant seed near edge of cup (can see roots through side!)
   - Press gently, don't bury too deep (rule: 2× seed depth)
   - Label with name and seed type

steps.title: Water & Placement (2 min)
steps.description: Gently water. Place in sunny location

steps.title: Reflection & Future Planning (2 min)
steps.description:
- What will we do each day to help seeds grow?
   - How is planting seeds like saving money? (Start small, grows over time, requires patience)

discussionQuestions: Why can't we have a plant today? What do we have to do?
In the story, Riley wanted results right away. Why did Frances say patience is important?
How is a seed library like a real library? (Borrow, return, share)
If one seed makes a plant with 100 new seeds, how many could you have next year?

45.label: 45 Minutes
45.bestFor: Block schedules, grades 3-4, deeper exploration Total time: 10 min story + 35 min activity = 45 minutes
materials: Variety of seeds (4-5 types: radish, bean, sunflower, tomato, herb)
Small envelopes or folded paper for seed packets

steps.title: Seed Science Exploration (8 min)
steps.description:
- Display and examine 4-5 seed varieties with magnifying glasses
   - Discuss seed anatomy: seed coat, embryo, food storage
   - Compare: size, shape, texture, what they'll become
   - Scientific observation: Draw each seed type, label parts
   - Read seed packet information: days to germination, care instructions
   - Discuss Frances's teaching: One tomato can give you seeds for 20+ plants. What does that mean for value over time?

steps.title: Create Seed Packets for Sharing (10 min)
steps.description:
- Each student makes 2 seed packets (like seed library concept)
   - Fold paper or use small envelopes
   - Design packet front: draw what plant will look like, name of plant, planting instructions
   - Fill with 5-10 seeds to share with classmate or take home
   - Discuss: How does sharing seeds help everyone? (Community wealth, multiplying resources)

steps.title: Detailed Observation Journal Setup (7 min)
steps.description:
- Create multi-page journal:
     - Page 1: Seed drawing and description
     - Page 2-6: Weekly observation pages (Date, Drawing, Height, Changes, Questions)
     - Page 7: Prediction vs. Reality reflection
   - First entry: Draw seed, measure it, describe it
   - Make prediction: I predict my seed will sprout in ___ days and be full-grown in ___ weeks

steps.title: Scientific Planting (6 min)
steps.description:
- Clear cup allows root observation
   - Measure and mark soil depth on cup
   - Plant seed at proper depth (2× seed size)
   - Plant multiple seeds at different depths to compare growth rates
   - Water with measured amount (document in journal)
   - Create detailed label: name, seed type, planting date, predicted sprout date

steps.title: FL Connection Discussion (4 min)
steps.description:
- Frances taught that small things saved and tended grow into greater value. How does this connect to money?
   - Chart on board: SEED → PLANT → VEGETABLES/FLOWERS → MORE SEEDS (multiplies!)
   - Compare to money: SMALL SAVINGS → GROWS OVER TIME → BECOMES LARGER AMOUNT
   - Introduce vocabulary: investment, patience, delayed gratification, compound growth
   - If you saved one dollar a week for a year, how much would you have? (Instant? No. Over time? $52!)

discussionQuestions: Why is starting with a tiny seed better than buying a full plant? (Cost, learning, multiplication)
Frances said waiting makes the result more valuable. Do you agree? Why?
If every student plants seeds that make 50 new seeds, how many could our whole class have?
What other things in life require patience before you see results? (Learning instrument, reading, saving money)
How does the seed library system help people who don't have money to buy plants?
What's the difference between instant gratification and delayed gratification? Which did Riley learn about?
extensionIdeas: Track growth over 4-6 weeks, graph height progression
Calculate total seeds produced if plant completes cycle
Research: How do farmers use saved seeds? Seed saving traditions
Create classroom seed library where students contribute and borrow
Compare cost: one seed packet vs. one full-grown plant at store
Document journey with photos, create Seed to Plant documentary

title.en: Trading Post: Swap & Share Fair Exchange
title.es: Trading Post: Swap & Share Fair Exchange

description.en: Trading Post: Swap & Share Fair Exchange
description.es: Trading Post: Swap & Share Fair Exchange

20.label: 20 Minutes
20.bestFor: Tight schedules, younger students (K-1), daily scheduling Total time: 10 min story + 10 min activity = 20 minutes
20.activityName: Trading Post: Swap & Share Fair Exchange
materials: Tables or desks for displaying items
Scrap paper for simple trading cards

steps.title: Gather & Display (3 min)
steps.description: Each student displays their 3-5 items on desk. Create simple label: I have: ___

steps.title: Browse & Choose (4 min)
steps.description: Students walk around looking at others' items. Think: What would I like to have?

steps.title: Quick Trading (4 min)
steps.description: Pair up students. Discuss one-for-one trades: I'll trade my extra eraser for your sticker. Both must agree

steps.title: Share Results (2 min)
steps.description: Quick circle share: I traded my ___ for ___. It's fair because ___

discussionQuestions: Did you have to use money to get something new?
What makes a trade fair?
How does trading help both people?

30.label: 30 Minutes
30.bestFor: Standard class periods, grades 1-3, weekly scheduling Total time: 10 min story + 20 min activity = 30 minutes
30.activityName: Trading Post: Swap & Share Fair Exchange
materials: Index cards or paper for trading cards
Table or desk space for trading post
Optional: stickers for condition rating (1-3 stars)

steps.title: Create Trading Cards (6 min)
steps.description:
- Each student makes simple card for each item
   - Write: item name, draw picture
   - Mark condition: ⭐ (fair), ⭐⭐ (good), ⭐⭐⭐ (like new)
   - Assign simple value: 1 star = 1 point, 2 stars = 2 points, 3 stars = 3 points

steps.title: Set Up Trading Post (3 min)
steps.description:
- Arrange items by category on tables (Books, Toys, Games, Art)
   - Place trading card next to each item
   - Create Fair Trade Rules sign: Both sides agree, Equal points, Good condition

steps.title: Trading Time (8 min)
steps.description:
- Students browse and find items they want
   - Check point values
   - Offer their item(s) with equal points: My 2-point book for your 2-point toy?
   - Negotiate and agree before swapping
   - Teacher monitors for fairness

steps.title: Reflection Circle (3 min)
steps.description: - Sit together and share: What did you trade? Was it fair? Did anyone use money?

discussionQuestions: How did Ellis's system in the story help make trades fair?
What made your item valuable even though it's used?
Would you rather trade or buy new? Why?
How does trading help people who don't have money to spend?

45.label: 45 Minutes
45.bestFor: Block schedules, grades 3-4, deeper exploration Total time: 10 min story + 35 min activity = 45 minutes
45.activityName: Trading Post: Swap & Share Fair Exchange
materials: Cardstock or index cards for professional trading cards
Tables for organized display by category
Optional: play money or tokens representing trade points

steps.title: Value Assessment Training (7 min)
steps.description:
- Review rubric together:
     - **Condition:** Like new (3 pts), Good (2 pts), Fair (1 pt)
     - **Desirability:** High demand (+1), Medium (0), Low (-1)
     - **Size/Complexity:** Large/complex (+1), Medium (0), Small (-1)
   - Practice assessing 2-3 sample items as class
   - Each student assesses their own items and assigns value (1-5 points)

steps.title: Create Professional Trading Cards (8 min)
steps.description:
- For each item, create card with:
     - Item name and detailed description
     - Condition rating with justification
     - Total trade value (1-5 points)
     - Owner's name
   - Make cards visually appealing (colors, borders, drawings)

steps.title: Organize Trading Post (5 min)
steps.description:
- Set up tables by category (Books, Toys, Games, Art Supplies, Other)
   - Display items with cards
   - Create Trading Post Rules poster:
     - Both parties must agree
     - Trade values should be within 1 point of equal
     - Multiple small items can trade for one large item
     - No take-backs after agreement

steps.title: Trading & Negotiation (10 min)
steps.description:
- Students browse with their total trade value budget
   - When interested in item: check value, offer equal-value trade
   - Practice negotiation: My 4-point game for your 3-point book and 1-point toy?
   - Document each trade on sheet: WHO + WHAT + VALUES

steps.title: Data Analysis & Reflection (5 min)
steps.description:
- Quick tally: How many trades? Total value exchanged (no money!)?
   - Most popular category?
   - Individual reflection: What did I learn about value? How did trading without money feel?

discussionQuestions: Was it harder to agree on value with used items or would it be easier with new items? Why?
What happened when lots of people wanted the same item? (supply and demand)
How did you feel when negotiating? What strategies worked?
In the story, some kids only wanted to take. How did Ellis solve that?
Could a whole community work on trading instead of money? What would be challenges?
When is bartering better than buying? When is buying better?
extensionIdeas: Research historical barter systems (Silk Road, colonial America)
Design a digital trading app: What features would make trading easy?
Host trading event with another class or families
Create trade advertisements to market items

20.label: 20 Minutes
20.bestFor: Tight schedules, younger students (K-1), daily scheduling, indoor exploration alternative Total time: 10 min story + 10 min activity = 20 minutes
materials: Collection of nature items (smooth stones, sticks, leaves, pinecones)
Paper for simple journal pages (folded in half = instant journal)
Optional: magnifying glass for close observation

steps.title: Map Introduction (2 min)
steps.description: Show simple neighborhood map or drawing. Where might we find creeks near us? What would a map show?

steps.title: Nature Item Observation (4 min)
steps.description: Display creek treasures pre-collected (stones, interesting sticks). Students touch, observe textures, notice smooth vs. rough

steps.title: Quick Drawing Activity (3 min)
steps.description: Draw one favorite nature item in journal. Add simple label if able (smooth stone, bumpy stick)

steps.title: Sharing Circle (1 min)
steps.description: Each student shows drawing and says one thing they noticed

discussionQuestions: What do you notice about these creek stones? How do they feel?
Why do you think stones in a creek become smooth?
What would you want to find if we could explore a real creek?

30.label: 30 Minutes
30.bestFor: Standard class periods, grades 1-3, weekly scheduling Total time: 10 min story + 20 min activity = 30 minutes
materials: Small collection bags or containers (one per student or pair)
Simple map of exploration area (hand-drawn is fine)
Optional: basic magnifying glasses, field guide reference cards showing common items

steps.title: Explorer Prep (3 min)
steps.description: Review outdoor safety rules (stay with buddy, stay in boundaries, no touching unknown plants). Distribute journals and collection bags. Assign buddy pairs

steps.title: Outdoor Exploration (10 min)
steps.description:
- Walk to nearest outdoor area (schoolyard corner, nearby park, nature trail)
   - Follow simple map showing route and observation stops
   - Collect safe items: leaves, acorns, smooth stones, interesting sticks, seedpods
   - Practice noticing: textures (rough/smooth), colors, patterns, sounds of nature

steps.title: Collection Review (3 min)
steps.description: Gather in circle outdoors or back in classroom. Each pair shares one favorite discovery and why they chose it

steps.title: Journal Documentation (3 min)
steps.description: Draw or trace 2-3 collected items in journal. Add labels or simple descriptions (I found a smooth gray stone)

steps.title: Reflection (1 min)
steps.description: What surprised you about exploring today? What would you like to find next time?

discussionQuestions: What tools do explorers need besides maps? (eyes to observe, ears to listen, curiosity!)
How did working with a buddy help you explore?
What can you learn from looking closely at one small thing?

45.label: 45 Minutes
45.bestFor: Block schedules, grades 3-4, deeper exploration Total time: 10 min story + 35 min activity = 45 minutes
materials: Collection bags with labels for different categories
Field identification cards (leaves, rocks, insects if safe)
Optional: camera or tablets for photo documentation
Clipboard or hard surface for outdoor writing

steps.title: Scientific Method Prep (4 min)
steps.description:
- Introduce how scientists observe and document in field
   - Demonstrate journal entry: date, location, weather, detailed sketch with labels, written observations, questions
   - Review safety protocols and explorer ethics (leave no trace, observe don't harm, respect all living things)

steps.title: Extended Outdoor Exploration (15 min)
steps.description:
- Explore outdoor area with specific observation missions:
     * Find 3 different leaf shapes and identify characteristics
     * Locate items with different textures (smooth stone like story, rough bark, soft moss)
     * Observe signs of water flow or imagine how water would move through area
     * Notice signs of wildlife (tracks, nests, nibbled plants, holes in ground)
   - Collect specimens responsibly (nothing living, only abundant items)
   - Take measurements (circumference of tree trunk, length of found stick, dimensions of largest stone)

steps.title: Scientific Documentation (8 min)
steps.description:
- Create detailed multi-part journal entries:
     * Header: Date, time, location, weather conditions, temperature if available
     * Detailed sketches with arrows and labels pointing to specific features
     * Written observations (texture, size comparisons, color descriptions, where item was found)
     * Measurement data recorded in table format
     * Personal questions for further research (Why is this bark peeling? How old is this tree?)

steps.title: Identification & Research (4 min)
steps.description:
- Use simple field guides to attempt identification
   - Add scientific or common names to journal if identified
   - Group similar items (all rocks together, all leaves together)

steps.title: Team Sharing & Synthesis (3 min)
steps.description:
- Small groups (3-4 students) share most interesting discovery
   - Discuss: What patterns did you notice? What connections did you see between items?

steps.title: Future Investigation Planning (1 min)
steps.description: Students write one question they want to explore more deeply next time

discussionQuestions: What patterns did you notice in the natural items we observed?
How do scientists document their discoveries differently than artists might?
Why is it important to observe habitats without disturbing them?
What does a healthy ecosystem need? What evidence did you see of this?
How did teamwork help us explore more safely and see more things?
What's the difference between just walking outside and truly exploring like a scientist?
extensionIdeas: Research one collected specimen in depth (where it came from, how it formed, what organisms interact with it)
Write adventure narrative based on today's exploration, incorporating real observations
Design comprehensive Explorer's Field Guide with entries for each type of item found
Plan to revisit same site each month to track seasonal changes over school year

chapterTitle.es: El Puesto de Arte de Riley

20.label: 20 Minutes
20.bestFor: Tight schedules, younger students (K-1), daily scheduling Total time: 10 min story + 10 min activity = 20 minutes
materials: Optional: natural materials for decoration (leaves, flowers)

steps.title: Confidence Talk (2 min)
steps.description: Like Riley, we all have talents to share. What do you like to create? Brief affirmation discussion

steps.title: Art Creation (5 min)
steps.description: Each student creates one simple artwork (nature drawing, pattern, free expression)

steps.title: Sharing Circle (2 min)
steps.description: Students hold up art, say one thing they like about it, hear one positive comment from peer

steps.title: Gift Option (1 min)
steps.description: Choose to give art to classmate or take home as gift for family member

discussionQuestions: What did you create? What makes it special?
How does it feel to share your art?
Is your art valuable even if you give it away for free?

30.label: 30 Minutes
30.bestFor: Standard class periods, grades 1-3, weekly scheduling Total time: 10 min story + 20 min activity = 30 minutes
materials: Optional: watercolors, chalk, pastels, natural materials
Small table or desk area for stand
Materials for Free Art sign (cardboard, markers)
Folder or envelope for finished pieces

steps.title: Riley's Journey Discussion (3 min)
steps.description: Review Riley's fear and growth. What skills could you share? What might stop you?

steps.title: Art Production (8 min)
steps.description: Each student creates 2-3 small artworks (cards, bookmarks, drawings)

steps.title: Stand Setup (3 min)
steps.description: Arrange classroom space as art stand. Create Free Art - Take One! signs together

steps.title: Teaching Practice (4 min)
steps.description: Pair up. Each student teaches partner one technique or favorite art approach

steps.title: Gallery Walk (2 min)
steps.description: Browse classroom stands, select one classmate artwork to appreciate or take (if doing exchange)

discussionQuestions: What was it like to teach someone your technique?
How did you feel when someone appreciated your work?
Why did Riley choose to give her art for free? Would it be okay to sell it instead?
What did you receive today that wasn't bought with money?

45.label: 45 Minutes
45.bestFor: Block schedules, grades 3-4, deeper exploration Total time: 10 min story + 35 min activity = 45 minutes
materials: Multiple art mediums (markers, crayons, colored pencils, watercolors, pastels, chalk)
Optional: simple frames or display boards

steps.title: Deep Value Discussion (5 min)
steps.description: What gifts have you received that weren't bought? What talents do you have that others might enjoy learning? How does value exist beyond price?

steps.title: Skill Inventory (3 min)
steps.description: Students identify their artistic strengths (drawing, color use, patterns, nature art, teaching ability)

steps.title: Art Production (12 min)
steps.description:
- Create 3-5 pieces to share
   - Include variety (some to give away, some to teach from)
   - Write brief artist statement for at least one piece (Gr 2-4)

steps.title: Professional Stand Design (5 min)
steps.description:
- Create attractive signage
   - Organize artwork display thoughtfully
   - Prepare demonstration/teaching area

steps.title: Teaching Rotations (6 min)
steps.description:
- Students rotate teaching their technique to 2-3 classmates
   - Practice explaining process clearly
   - Receive questions and give feedback

steps.title: Community Sharing (3 min)
steps.description:
- Invite another class, school staff, or families to visit stands
   - Give away art and teach techniques
   - Document with photos

steps.title: Reflection (2 min)
steps.description: Written or verbal reflection on experience

discussionQuestions: What's the difference between selling your art and giving it away? Are both okay?
How did people respond when you shared your talents?
What skills did you learn from others today that didn't cost money?
Why do you think the community gave Riley gifts even though she didn't ask for payment?
How can sharing what you're good at make your neighborhood better?
What other skills besides art could people share in a 'free stand'?
extensionIdeas: Set up real art stand at school entrance or community location
Create skill sharing board where students offer to teach various talents
Document journey in art journal
Plan Free Fridays where different students share different skills weekly
Write thank-you notes to those who appreciated art

20.label: 20 Minutes
20.bestFor: Tight schedules, younger students (K-1), daily scheduling Total time: 10 min story + 10 min activity = 20 minutes
materials: Small container (recycled jar, cup, or envelope)

steps.title: Coin Introduction (2 min)
steps.description: Show penny, nickel, dime, quarter. Name each, identify values

steps.title: Sorting Activity (4 min)
steps.description: Each student gets mixed coins (real or printed). Sort by type into piles

steps.title: Counting Practice (3 min)
steps.description: Count each pile. How many pennies? How many dimes?

steps.title: Record Total (1 min)
steps.description: Write or draw totals. I have ___ coins!

discussionQuestions: Which coin is worth the most?
If you found one coin every day, how many would you have in a week?
What could you buy with many pennies?

30.label: 30 Minutes
30.bestFor: Standard class periods, grades 1-3, weekly scheduling Total time: 10 min story + 20 min activity = 30 minutes
materials: Clear jar or container for each student/group
Optional: play money for additional practice

steps.title: Intro & Coin Review (3 min)
steps.description: Review coin values. Demonstrate counting mixed coins

steps.title: Found Coins Distribution (2 min)
steps.description: Give each student/group a small collection of mixed coins (representing what they found)

steps.title: Sorting by Type (4 min)
steps.description: Sort coins into penny, nickel, dime, quarter piles

steps.title: Counting & Recording (6 min)
steps.description: Count each pile, record on tracking sheet. Calculate total value

steps.title: Savings Jar Creation (3 min)
steps.description: Place coins in jar. Decorate jar with label: [Name]'s Savings or Our Class Treasure

steps.title: Goal Discussion (2 min)
steps.description: If we kept finding coins, what could we save for? Brainstorm ideas

discussionQuestions: How many pennies equal one dime?
What's easier to count: all pennies or mixed coins? Why?
What's something small you could save for?
Would you rather have 10 pennies or 1 dime? Why?

45.label: 45 Minutes
45.bestFor: Block schedules, grades 3-4, deeper exploration Total time: 10 min story + 35 min activity = 45 minutes
materials: Clear jars (one per student or small group)
Detailed tracking sheets with columns (Date, Coin Type, Value, Running Total)
Price tags for small classroom items

steps.title: Advanced Coin Intro (4 min)
steps.description: Review values, teach skip-counting (5s for nickels, 10s for dimes, 25s for quarters)

steps.title: Initial Found Coins Collection (3 min)
steps.description: Distribute starting coins (e.g., $2.37 in mixed denominations)

steps.title: Comprehensive Sorting & Counting (8 min)
steps.description:
- Sort by type
   - Count using skip-counting strategies
   - Record on detailed tracking sheet
   - Calculate total value

steps.title: Visual Representation (6 min)
steps.description:
- Create bar graph showing quantity of each coin type
   - OR pie chart showing percentage of total value from each coin type

steps.title: Economics Exploration (8 min)
steps.description:
- Display price tags on classroom items (eraser=$0.25, pencil=$0.50, book=$2.00)
   - Students calculate: What could I buy with my found coins?
   - How many more pennies would I need to afford the book?

steps.title: Group Decision Simulation (4 min)
steps.description:
- Pool class coins together
   - Calculate total
   - Discuss and vote: Save for something big together? Split evenly? Donate?

steps.title: Reflection & Planning (2 min)
steps.description: Each student writes one sentence about their coin-saving plan

discussionQuestions: Why do different coins have different values?
Is it better to find one quarter or four pennies? Why?
What's a realistic saving goal if you found coins every week?
What are the trade-offs between spending now and saving for later?
How did your group make a fair decision about the money?
extensionIdeas: Track actual found coins for a month, graph progress
Research what items cost historically vs. today
Write story problems: If Layla finds 3 pennies and Riley finds 2 dimes...
Create a classroom economy where students earn/spend coins

description.es: Build a Fort Challenge & Blueprint Design

20.label: 20 Minutes
20.bestFor: Tight schedules, younger students (K-1), daily scheduling Total time: 10 min story + 10 min activity = 20 minutes
20.activityName: Build a Fort Challenge & Blueprint Design

steps.title: Brainstorm (2 min)
steps.description: What makes a good fort? What do you need? (roof, walls, door)

steps.title: Quick Sketch (3 min)
steps.description: Each student draws simple fort plan on paper

steps.title: Mini Build (4 min)
steps.description: Using small materials, build tiny tabletop fort model

steps.title: Share & Celebrate (1 min)
steps.description: Show classmates, say one thing you like about your fort

discussionQuestions: What was hardest about building your fort?
How did you make it stay up?
If you built a real fort, what would you use?

30.label: 30 Minutes
30.bestFor: Standard class periods, grades 1-3, weekly scheduling Total time: 10 min story + 20 min activity = 30 minutes
30.activityName: Build a Fort Challenge & Blueprint Design
materials: Blankets or sheets (old ones from home)

steps.title: Team Formation & Planning (4 min)
steps.description: Groups of 3-4. Discuss: What will our fort look like? What's our plan?

steps.title: Blueprint Creation (5 min)
steps.description: Each group draws fort blueprint showing walls, roof, entrance, special features

steps.title: Material Gathering (2 min)
steps.description: Collect assigned materials from classroom supply station

steps.title: Building Time (7 min)
steps.description: Work together to build fort following blueprint

steps.title: Problem-Solving Check-In (1 min)
steps.description: What's not working? How can we fix it?

steps.title: Gallery Walk & Celebration (1 min)
steps.description: Visit other groups' forts, appreciate different designs

discussionQuestions: Did your fort turn out like your blueprint? What changed?
How did you solve problems when something didn't work?
What would you do differently next time?

45.label: 45 Minutes
45.bestFor: Block schedules, grades 3-4, deeper exploration Total time: 10 min story + 35 min activity = 45 minutes
45.activityName: Build a Fort Challenge & Blueprint Design
materials: Duct tape, masking tape, string, rope
Engineering Challenge Cards (optional: stability test, weight test, ventilation test)

steps.title: Engineering Introduction (3 min)
steps.description: Discuss real architects and engineers. Show images of different fort/shelter types

steps.title: Team Formation & Role Assignment (3 min)
steps.description:
- Groups of 4-5
   - Roles: Lead Architect (draws plans), Materials Manager (gathers supplies), Construction Lead (builds), Quality Checker (tests stability), Reporter (documents process)

steps.title: Detailed Blueprint Phase (8 min)
steps.description:
- Draw scaled blueprint with measurements
   - Label all features (walls, roof, door, windows)
   - List materials needed
   - Predict challenges

steps.title: Material Gathering & Prep (3 min)
steps.description: Materials Manager gathers supplies while team reviews plan

steps.title: Construction Phase (12 min)
steps.description:
- Build fort following blueprint
   - Test stability as you go
   - Make adjustments when needed

steps.title: Engineering Tests (4 min)
steps.description:
- Stability Test: Can fort stand without holding it?
   - Capacity Test: How many people fit inside comfortably?
   - Ventilation Test: Can you breathe well inside? (safety!)

steps.title: Documentation & Reflection (2 min)
steps.description:
- Take photo of finished fort
   - Each student writes: The hardest part was... We solved it by...

discussionQuestions: How did having specific roles help your team?
What was your biggest challenge and how did you overcome it?
If you could build a real outdoor fort, what materials would you choose? Why?
How is building together different from building alone?
extensionIdeas: Multi-day project: Refine and improve fort over several sessions
Outdoor version: Build real fort in schoolyard using branches, tarps
STEM connection: Research different types of shelters around the world
Write instruction manual for future fort builders

title.en: From Garden to Table: Simple Cooking & Cost Comparison
title.es: From Garden to Table: Simple Cooking & Cost Comparison

chapterTitle.es: La Caja de Recetas de Frances

description.en: From Garden to Table: Simple Cooking & Cost Comparison
description.es: From Garden to Table: Simple Cooking & Cost Comparison

20.label: 20 Minutes
20.bestFor: Tight schedules, younger students (K-1), daily scheduling, no-cook option Total time: 10 min story + 10 min activity = 20 minutes
20.activityName: From Garden to Table: Simple Cooking & Cost Comparison
materials: Hummus or ranch dip (store-bought or homemade)

steps.title: Price Discussion (2 min)
steps.description: Show price tags. How much did these carrots cost? How many servings can we make?

steps.title: Assembly (5 min)
steps.description: Each student arranges vegetables and dip on plate, adds crackers

steps.title: Cost Comparison (2 min)
steps.description: If we bought snack packs at store, they cost $2 each. We made these for about 50¢ each!

steps.title: Enjoy & Reflect (1 min)
steps.description: Eat together, discuss: Which costs less? Which is healthier?

discussionQuestions: How much money did we save by making our own snacks?
What vegetables did we use?
Would you rather buy a snack or make one? Why?

30.label: 30 Minutes
30.bestFor: Standard class periods, grades 1-3, weekly scheduling Total time: 10 min story + 20 min activity = 30 minutes
30.activityName: From Garden to Table: Simple Cooking & Cost Comparison
materials: Small bags or containers for each student
Paper and pencils for cost calculations

steps.title: Recipe & Cost Introduction (4 min)
steps.description:
- Show recipe: 2 cups cereal + 1 cup raisins + 1 cup pretzels + 1/2 cup chocolate chips = 4.5 cups total
   - Display costs: Cereal $3 (makes 10 cups), Raisins $4 (makes 4 cups), Pretzels $2 (makes 6 cups)
   - Today we'll figure out how much our homemade trail mix costs!

steps.title: Mixing (6 min)
steps.description:
- Students take turns measuring and adding ingredients to large bowl
   - Practice measuring: This is 1 cup. This is 1/2 cup.
   - Mix gently together

steps.title: Portioning (4 min)
steps.description:
- Divide trail mix into individual portions (about 1/2 cup each)
   - Students fill their take-home bags

steps.title: Cost Comparison (4 min)
steps.description:
- Calculate together: We spent $9 on ingredients and made 9 servings. That's $1 per serving.
   - Compare: Store-bought trail mix costs $3-4 per serving!
   - We saved $2-3 per person by making it ourselves.

steps.title: Enjoy & Reflect (2 min)
steps.description: Taste trail mix, discuss savings and taste

discussionQuestions: How much did each ingredient cost?
How many servings did we make?
How much money did we save compared to buying trail mix at the store?
What else could we make from scratch to save money?

45.label: 45 Minutes
45.bestFor: Block schedules, grades 3-4, deeper exploration, includes baking Total time: 10 min story + 35 min activity = 45 minutes
45.activityName: From Garden to Table: Simple Cooking & Cost Comparison
materials: - Optional: 1 cup blueberries or chocolate chips

steps.title: Cost Analysis Pre-Activity (6 min)
steps.description:
- Display all ingredients with actual prices
   - Today we're baking 12 muffins. Let's figure out the total cost!
   - Students help add up ingredient costs: Total = $2.42 for 12 muffins
   - Calculate per-muffin cost: $2.42 ÷ 12 = $0.20 per muffin
   - Compare to store: Bakery muffin costs $2-3 each!
   - We're saving $1.80-2.80 per muffin!

steps.title: Recipe Review & Safety (3 min)
steps.description:
- Read recipe aloud together
   - Review kitchen safety: wash hands, careful with hot oven, no tasting raw batter with egg
   - Assign roles: measurers, mixers, scoopers

steps.title: Mixing Dry Ingredients (4 min)
steps.description:
- Measure flour, sugar, baking powder, salt into large bowl
   - Whisk together

steps.title: Mixing Wet Ingredients (4 min)
steps.description:
- Measure milk, crack egg, add oil into medium bowl
   - Whisk together until combined

steps.title: Combining & Optional Add-Ins (4 min)
steps.description:
- Pour wet ingredients into dry ingredients
   - Stir gently until just combined (don't overmix!)
   - Fold in blueberries or chocolate chips if using

steps.title: Filling Muffin Tin (3 min)
steps.description:
- Place liners in muffin tin
   - Scoop batter evenly into 12 cups (about 3/4 full)

steps.title: Baking (15 min - can overlap with discussion)
steps.description:
- Adult places tin in preheated oven at 375°F
   - Bake 15-18 minutes
   - Meanwhile, complete cost analysis worksheet

steps.title: Cost Analysis Worksheet (during baking, 10 min)
steps.description:
- Students complete detailed breakdown:
     - List each ingredient and cost
     - Add up total cost
     - Divide by number of muffins
     - Compare to store prices
     - Calculate total savings if making weekly

steps.title: Cooling, Tasting & Reflection (6 min)
steps.description:
- Remove muffins, let cool 5 minutes
   - Taste test!
   - Discuss: How do they taste? Was it hard? Would you make these at home?

discussionQuestions: What was the total cost of ingredients?
How much did each muffin cost us to make?
How does that compare to buying muffins at a bakery or store?
If you made muffins once a week for a year, how much money would you save?
What other foods could we make from scratch instead of buying?
What skills did Frances teach the friends that we used today?
extensionIdeas: Students copy recipe to take home
Create cost comparison poster showing homemade vs. store-bought foods
Research other recipes and calculate costs
Interview family member about a recipe they make from scratch

20.label: 20 Minutes
20.bestFor: Tight schedules, younger students (K-1), daily scheduling Total time: 10 min story + 10 min activity = 20 minutes
materials: Optional: damaged books from classroom library

steps.title: Problem Introduction (2 min)
steps.description: Show torn paper/book. Is this ruined? Can we fix it?

steps.title: Demonstration (3 min)
steps.description: Teacher demonstrates taping torn edge carefully on both sides

steps.title: Practice (4 min)
steps.description: Each student receives torn paper, practices taping repair

steps.title: Test & Reflect (1 min)
steps.description: Does page turn? Can you read it? Is it good enough?

discussionQuestions: How did Benny feel when his train broke?
What did Mr. Mason teach them to do?
Can we use this book again now that it's repaired?

30.label: 30 Minutes
30.bestFor: Standard class periods, grades 1-3, weekly scheduling Total time: 10 min story + 20 min activity = 30 minutes

steps.title: Story Connection (3 min)
steps.description: Discuss Benny's broken train, Mr. Mason's solution

steps.title: Repair Stations Setup (2 min)
steps.description:
- Station 1: Paper/book repair (tape)
   - Station 2: Crayon repair (tape two halves together)
   - Station 3: Toy repair (glue, rubber bands)

steps.title: Demonstration (4 min)
steps.description: Show one repair technique at each station

steps.title: Hands-On Repair (8 min)
steps.description: Students rotate through stations, repair 2-3 items

steps.title: Cost Comparison (2 min)
steps.description: New book costs $8. Tape costs 10¢. We saved $7.90!

steps.title: Celebration (1 min)
steps.description: Show repaired items, celebrate success

discussionQuestions: What was broken? How did you fix it?
How much would it cost to buy new vs. repair?
How do you feel about the item now that you fixed it?
What else at home could you repair?

45.label: 45 Minutes
45.bestFor: Block schedules, grades 3-4, deeper exploration Total time: 10 min story + 35 min activity = 45 minutes
materials: - Clear tape, duct tape, masking tape

steps.title: Opening Discussion (4 min)
steps.description:
- Review Benny's story
   - How many of you have thrown away something broken that could have been fixed?
   - Introduce today's goal: repair items, calculate savings

steps.title: Item Assessment (6 min)
steps.description:
- Each student examines their broken item
   - Complete Repair Assessment worksheet:
     - What's broken?
     - What materials needed?
     - Estimated repair time
     - Cost to replace vs. cost to repair

steps.title: Repair Planning (4 min)
steps.description:
- Match item to appropriate repair technique
   - Gather needed materials
   - Review safety (glue, needles, scissors)

steps.title: Hands-On Repair Time (15 min)
steps.description:
- Students work on repairs with teacher/volunteer support
   - Take before and after photos
   - Test repaired items

steps.title: Cost Analysis Activity (4 min)
steps.description:
- Calculate replacement cost (look up online or estimate)
   - Calculate repair cost (materials used)
   - Determine savings per item
   - Add up class total savings

steps.title: Reflection & Sharing (2 min)
steps.description:
- Students share: I repaired [item]. It would have cost $[X] to replace. I saved $[Y]!
   - Discuss feelings: frustration → problem-solving → accomplishment

discussionQuestions: What was the hardest part of repairing?
Did your item turn out perfect, or 'good enough'? Is that okay?
How much money did our class save total by repairing instead of replacing?
If you repaired one item per month, how much would you save in a year?
How does repairing help the environment?
What did you learn about yourself as a 'fixer'?
extensionIdeas: Start classroom Repair Cafe where students help each other fix things
Research Right to Repair movement
Calculate environmental impact (items diverted from landfill)

title.en: My Library Card & Book Care Challenge
title.es: My Library Card & Book Care Challenge

description.en: My Library Card & Book Care Challenge
description.es: My Library Card & Book Care Challenge

20.label: 20 Minutes
20.bestFor: Tight schedules, younger students (K-1), daily scheduling Total time: 10 min story + 10 min activity = 20 minutes
20.activityName: My Library Card & Book Care Challenge

steps.title: Library Discussion (2 min)
steps.description: What is a library? Who has been to one? What can you do there?

steps.title: Card Design (5 min)
steps.description: Each student creates a pretend library card with their name, card number (teacher provides), simple decoration

steps.title: Book Care Intro (2 min)
steps.description: Show proper way to hold book, turn pages gently, use bookmarks (not folding!)

steps.title: Sharing (1 min)
steps.description: Students show their cards, practice saying I'd like to check out this book, please

discussionQuestions: What can you do at a library besides borrow books?
Why is it important to take care of library books?
What kind of book would you like to find at the library?

30.label: 30 Minutes
30.bestFor: Standard class periods, grades 1-3, weekly scheduling Total time: 10 min story + 20 min activity = 30 minutes
30.activityName: My Library Card & Book Care Challenge
materials: Date stamp OR stickers for due date
Small containers or bags for taking books home

steps.title: Library Introduction (3 min)
steps.description: Discuss what libraries offer (books, movies, computers, games, programs, story time—all FREE!)

steps.title: Card Design (8 min)
steps.description: Students create library cards including: name, library card number, simple personal design/decoration. Optional: laminate with clear tape

steps.title: Book Care Workshop (4 min)
steps.description: Demonstrate proper handling—two hands, gentle pages, bookmarks not folding, keeping books away from food/water

steps.title: Checkout Practice (4 min)
steps.description: Set up simple checkout desk. Students select classroom book, approach desk, present library card, librarian stamps due date, student says thank you

steps.title: Reflection (1 min)
steps.description: How does the library save families money? What will you look for at your real library?

discussionQuestions: What happens if library books get damaged or lost?
How can we take care of books so everyone can enjoy them?
What free programs might your library offer? (story time, crafts, computer use)

45.label: 45 Minutes
45.bestFor: Block schedules, grades 3-4, deeper exploration Total time: 10 min story + 35 min activity = 45 minutes
45.activityName: My Library Card & Book Care Challenge
materials: Laminating sheets or clear contact paper
Diverse classroom books organized by category
Date stamp or calendar for due dates
Librarian badge for rotating student role

steps.title: Library Economics Discussion (4 min)
steps.description:
- Create cost comparison on board: Buying 3 books = $15-25 vs. Library card = $0, Borrowing 3 books = $0
   - Discuss how libraries are funded (community taxes so everyone has equal access)
   - What libraries offer besides books: programs, computers, meeting rooms, free events

steps.title: Professional Card Creation (10 min)
steps.description:
- Students design cards with all elements: full name, card number, date issued, personal design
   - Laminate or cover with contact paper
   - Optional: punch hole and add lanyard

steps.title: Library System Stations (15 min) - Rotate through 3 stations (5 min each)
steps.description:
- **Station 1 - Book Care:** Practice proper handling, identifying book damage, using bookmarks, carrying books safely
   - **Station 2 - Browsing & Selection:** Learn how books are organized (fiction/nonfiction, easy/chapter books), practice selecting books by interest
   - **Station 3 - Checkout & Return:** Practice full process—browse, select, approach desk, present card, receive book with due date, return process

steps.title: Full Simulation (4 min)
steps.description: Students use new library cards to check out actual classroom books, following complete procedure

steps.title: Library Exploration Planning (2 min)
steps.description: Each student identifies one thing they'd look for at their real library (specific book topic, program type, etc.)

discussionQuestions: Why do you think communities decided to create public libraries?
What are your responsibilities as a library card holder?
Besides saving money, what other benefits do libraries provide? (learning, community gathering, internet access, etc.)
How would you teach a younger child to care for library books?
extensionIdeas: Virtual tour of local library website
Create book care reminder bookmarks for classmates
Write thank-you letters to school or local librarian
Track class library visits over a month
Research library history or Carnegie libraries

20.label: 20 Minutes
20.bestFor: Tight schedules, younger students (K-1), daily scheduling Total time: 10 min story + 10 min activity = 20 minutes
materials: Paper and crayons for simple share tags

steps.title: Growth Reflection (2 min)
steps.description: Remember when friends planted seeds in Chapter 2? Now they've grown! What do plants need to grow?

steps.title: Abundance Simulation (4 min)
steps.description: Give each student/group 10-15 paper vegetables. You only need 5 for your family. What should you do with the extra?

steps.title: Sharing Decision (3 min)
steps.description: Students decide how many to keep vs. share. Place share vegetables in community basket

steps.title: Quick Gratitude (1 min)
steps.description: How do you think neighbors feel when they receive vegetables?

discussionQuestions: Is it better to share extra or keep it all? Why?
How does sharing make you feel?

30.label: 30 Minutes
30.bestFor: Standard class periods, grades 1-3, weekly scheduling Total time: 10 min story + 20 min activity = 30 minutes
materials: Small baskets, bags, or created paper baskets
Craft supplies for decorating baskets (markers, stickers, ribbon)
Thank you for growing cards (template provided)

steps.title: Investment Review (3 min)
steps.description: Discuss Chapter 2 planting. What did it cost? Seeds=$0.50, time=30 min. What did it produce? Calculate value

steps.title: Harvest Counting (5 min)
steps.description: Students receive mixed paper vegetables (tomatoes, carrots, lettuce). Count and sort by type

steps.title: Needs vs. Surplus (4 min)
steps.description: Your family needs 6 vegetables. You harvested 15. How many extra do you have? Record on chart

steps.title: Basket Creation (5 min)
steps.description: Students decorate small sharing baskets and fill with extra vegetables

steps.title: Gratitude Cards (2 min)
steps.description: Write or draw simple thank-you/sharing message: From our garden to you!

steps.title: Reflection (1 min)
steps.description: What happened when we shared? How might neighbors respond?

discussionQuestions: If you planted 3 seeds and each grew 8 tomatoes, how many total tomatoes?
Why did Layla suggest sharing instead of selling the vegetables?
What did neighbors share back in the story? Why?
How does sharing create community wealth instead of just one person's wealth?

45.label: 45 Minutes
45.bestFor: Block schedules, grades 3-4, deeper exploration Total time: 10 min story + 35 min activity = 45 minutes
materials: Decorating supplies (ribbon, markers, stickers, natural materials)

steps.title: Investment Economics Discussion (5 min)
steps.description:
- Review Chapter 2: Friends planted seeds. What did that cost in money? In time?
   - Calculate return: Seeds cost $0.50, produced $12 worth of vegetables. What's the return on investment?
   - Discuss: Why is this better than just buying vegetables each week?

steps.title: Abundance Recognition (6 min)
steps.description:
- Students receive harvest (15-20 mixed vegetables each/per group)
   - Count total harvest
   - Identify family needs (6-8 vegetables)
   - Calculate surplus: Total - Needs = Share amount
   - Record on tracking worksheet

steps.title: Sharing Decision Workshop (8 min)
steps.description:
- Discuss options: Keep all? Share some? Share all extra?
   - Pros/cons of each choice
   - Decision: How many to share, with whom?
   - Create sharing baskets with decorative elements
   - Write personalized cards: Grown with care, shared with love - from [name]'s garden

steps.title: Community Reciprocity Simulation (8 min)
steps.description:
- Students deliver baskets to designated classroom areas (representing neighbors)
   - Teacher provides neighbor response cards showing what was shared back (eggs, baked goods, flowers, thank-you notes)
   - Students receive responses
   - Discuss: You gave vegetables, but received other things. How does this create community wealth?

steps.title: Long-Term Growth Reflection (6 min)
steps.description:
- Timeline activity: Seeds (Ch. 2, 3 months ago) → Growth (weeks of waiting) → Harvest (today) → Sharing (creating connections)
   - Calculate: If you save seeds from this harvest for next year, how much could you grow?
   - Discuss abundance cycle: Share → Receive → Gratitude → Want to share more

steps.title: Gratitude Circle (2 min)
steps.description: Each student shares one thing they're grateful for about growth or sharing

discussionQuestions: What's the difference between abundance mentality ('enough for everyone') and scarcity mentality ('not enough, must hoard')?
In the story, when friends shared vegetables, neighbors shared other things. How does this create more wealth than money alone?
Why might sharing extra be smarter than trying to sell everything?
How does waiting 3 months for a harvest teach delayed gratification?
extensionIdeas: Track actual classroom/school garden from seed to harvest
Research food banks and community sharing programs
Calculate savings: homegrown vegetables vs. store-bought over a year
Create abundance mindset vs. scarcity mindset comparison chart
Write persuasive letter about community gardens

title.en: My Season 1 Treasure Exhibition & Reflection Celebration
title.es: My Season 1 Treasure Exhibition & Reflection Celebration

description.en: My Season 1 Treasure Exhibition & Reflection Celebration
description.es: My Season 1 Treasure Exhibition & Reflection Celebration

20.label: 20 Minutes
20.bestFor: Tight schedules, younger students (K-1), daily scheduling Total time: 10 min story + 10 min activity = 20 minutes
20.activityName: My Season 1 Treasure Exhibition & Reflection Celebration
materials: Optional: student work from previous chapters

steps.title: Chapter Review (3 min)
steps.description: Teacher quickly names all 12 chapters. Which was your favorite? Why?

steps.title: Treasure Identification (4 min)
steps.description: Students share one treasure they found/made/learned this season

steps.title: Drawing (2 min)
steps.description: Each student draws favorite treasure on small paper

steps.title: Celebration (1 min)
steps.description: We found so many treasures without spending money! We are treasure hunters!

discussionQuestions: What treasure did you find, make, or learn about?
Which chapter was your favorite?
What will you remember most?

30.label: 30 Minutes
30.bestFor: Standard class periods, grades 1-3, weekly scheduling Total time: 10 min story + 20 min activity = 30 minutes
30.activityName: My Season 1 Treasure Exhibition & Reflection Celebration
materials: Samples of student work from Season 1 chapters (if available)

steps.title: Season Review (4 min)
steps.description: Review all 12 chapters with visual prompts. Students identify what they learned in each

steps.title: Treasure Selection (4 min)
steps.description: Each student selects 3-5 treasures (learnings, creations, memories) to showcase

steps.title: Poster Creation (9 min)
steps.description:
- Divide poster into sections (Ch. 1: Nature, Ch. 2: Seeds, Ch. 3: Trading, etc.)
   - Students draw/write/attach work representing their treasures
   - Label each treasure with chapter number and title

steps.title: Gallery Walk (2 min)
steps.description: Students display posters, walk around to see classmates' treasures

steps.title: Reflection (1 min)
steps.description: What did we learn about finding treasures without buying them?

discussionQuestions: How did we save money this season? (repairing, growing food, borrowing from library, trading)
What treasure are you most proud of?
What will you keep doing after this season ends?

45.label: 45 Minutes
45.bestFor: Block schedules, grades 3-4, deeper exploration, culminating celebration Total time: 10 min story + 35 min activity = 45 minutes
45.activityName: My Season 1 Treasure Exhibition & Reflection Celebration
materials: Student work from all Season 1 chapters
Labels and chapter signs (Ch. 1 - Secret Garden, Ch. 2 - Seed Library, etc.)
Optional: actual items (repaired objects, nature collections, art, plants)

steps.title: Opening Reflection (5 min)
steps.description:
- Review Season 1 journey: all 12 chapters and themes
   - Discussion: What does 'treasure' mean? Is it only things you buy?
   - Introduce exhibition goal: Showcase our treasures to celebrate learning

steps.title: Exhibition Categories Setup (3 min)
steps.description:
- Assign exhibition booths or sections:
     - **Found Treasures:** Ch. 1 nature collections, Ch. 4 creek discoveries
     - **Grown Treasures:** Ch. 2 seeds, Ch. 11 harvest, Ch. 8 food from garden
     - **Made Treasures:** Ch. 5 Riley's art, Ch. 7 fort blueprints
     - **Fixed Treasures:** Ch. 9 repaired items
     - **Shared Treasures:** Ch. 3 trading post, Ch. 11 community baskets
     - **Free Treasures:** Ch. 6 penny hunt savings, Ch. 10 library cards

steps.title: Organizing Displays (10 min)
steps.description:
- Small groups work on one category booth
   - Arrange student work, label with chapter titles
   - Create simple signs explaining what was learned
   - Add visual appeal (borders, decorations)

steps.title: Individual Reflection Worksheet (7 min)
steps.description:
- Students complete My Season 1 Treasures reflection:
     - Favorite chapter and why
     - One thing I found, made, grew, fixed, or shared
     - One FL lesson I'll remember
     - Money saved this season (estimate from activities)
     - One treasure I'll continue finding/making

steps.title: Exhibition Presentations (8 min)
steps.description:
- Small groups present their booth (1 min each)
   - Explain what students learned and created in those chapters
   - Share specific examples of treasures

steps.title: Celebration & Certificates (2 min)
steps.description:
- Teacher presents certificates: Treasure Hunter - Season 1 Complete!
   - Class celebration: We found amazing treasures without spending lots of money!
   - Preview Season 2 (if applicable)

discussionQuestions: What treasure from Season 1 surprised you the most?
How much money did we save total across all chapters by finding, making, repairing, and borrowing instead of buying?
What skills did you learn that will help you find treasures in the future?
How is a 'treasure hunter' different from a 'shopper'?
What treasure will you look for next?
extensionIdeas: Create digital photo exhibition to share with families
Write letters to next year's students about treasure hunting
Plan first Season 2 treasure hunt
